summary: in healthy neurons, tau protein is enriched in the axon. tau accumulation in the cell body due to disruption of the AIS barrier is potentially a contributing factor to AD pathogenesis. aging causes altered neuronal protein expression, axonal atrophy, and some gliosis. fish 344 rats are a good model to recapitulate factors of human aging. aging causes alterations in AIS integrity and tau mislocalization. aging may represent events that contribute to aging as a strong risk factor for AD. the AIS is a selective diffusion barrier separating the axonal compartment from the somatodendritic compartment. the establishment of the AIS creates a filter that regulates intracellular traffic based on protein size or the type of motor proteins carrying cargo along microtubules. a single previous report showed that some structural proteins in the AIS are reduced with age in wild-type mice. saline perfusion followed by 200 ml phosphate buffered 4% paraformaldehyde. the brains were postfixed in Optical density measurement of tau immunofluorescence in the somata and axons of HP neurons shows no changes with advancing age. intensity of tau (using Tau7, a total tau antibody) in neurons in the CA1, CA2, CA3 and dentate regions of the HP shows no change with advancing age. significance between age groups was determined using one-way ANOVA. significance was set at p 0.05. if no overall significance was achieved, no post hoc analyses were used. we also probed blots with the R1 tau antibody, a pan-tau rabbit polyclonal antibody (F(2,12) = 0.7686, p = 0.4852; Fig. 1G) and found no aging-related changes. tubulin was analyzed to measure the amount of microtubules as a control since tau is a microtubule-associated protein. stereological assessment of AIS length and morphology Stereological analysis of the AIS length showed no differences in the total length of all AISs in the HP across age groups. a small but significant change was detected in the volume and diameter of CA2 neurons when comparing young and old animals. the measured length of the AIS in HP neurons was 32.86 1.99 m in young, 32.33 1.379 m in middle, and 31.53 1.361 m in old aged animals. the total length of AISs in the HP estimated with the spaceballs stereology probe is unchanged across age groups. in the CA regions did not show an age-related difference. analysis of tau intensity in HP strata enriched in axonal projections did not detect any change with age. no changes were detected between aged groups. additional AnkG protein bands were detected at 190 kDa that did not change with age. these represent other canonical isoforms that are not specific to the AIS. blots were probed with SMI-312, an axon-specific neurofilament antibody. tubulin was analyzed to measure the amount of microtubules. there was no change in III-tubulin across age groups. blots were probed for GFAP, a protein previously shown to change in HP lysates of aging rats. a small but significant change was detected in the volume and diameter of CA2 neurons when comparing young and old animals. the measured length of the AIS in HP neurons was 32.86 1.99 m in young, 32.33 1.379 m in middle, and 31.53 1.361 m in old aged animals. dentate gyrus of the HP at ages 4 (E), 14 (G) and 24 (I) months showed no change. Optical density measurements of tau levels in somata and axonal layers showed no change across age groups. the axonal enrichment of tau may deteriorate during the pathogenesis of AD. aging may lead to the discovery of previously unappreciated anomalous features. we evaluated age-related changes in tau and the AIS. a single study assessed the aging changes in the AIS and showed changes in ankyrin and spectrin proteins using Western blottings of aged mice. the discordant findings could be due to the use of rats instead of mice, the methods used to immunoblot ankyrin or the increased specificity of antibodies currently available. stereological analysis of the AIS was conducted using two complementary approaches. the space balls probe is an established methodology for detecting aging-related changes in fiber structures within the brain. the space balls probe showed a lack of age-related changes in AIS length and only a mild region-specific decrease in width and volume. rat was not an appropriate model of aging to use for this study. we included age groups that span the spectrum from young (4 months), middle (14 months) and old (24 months), which is near the end of the normal lifespan and a time at which aging-related impairments in memory and cognition occur. reviewers should present AIS and Tau data separately for each individual hippocampal region, including images and analyses for each. authors should conduct these measurements in the axonal compartment Discussion 1. Discuss findings by Baalman et al (2012). techniques to demonstrate that normal ageing is not associated with large alterations in the composition or morphology of the axon initial segment (AIS), nor with large changes in somatic tau. the data presented in Figures 2 and 3 would be much stronger if presented separately for all individual regions of the hippocampus (i.e. CA1 vs CA3 vs DG) study examined whether aging affects AIS and tau distribution in Fischer 344 rats. authors found that axon initial segment (AIS) structure, AIS protein levels, the distribution of tau in neurons of the hippocampus, and total tau or phospho-tau protein levels were not different. the author missed some numbers before ‘mths’. in Fig 2G-I, what dose different color line mean.
